channel.title: For all you firefox hoes
channel.description:
Well, i came across this very nice feature that sort of speeds up your Firefox by changing the way it works. This feature will make your Firefox browser load multiple things at the same time instead of just one thing.
This feature is Pipelining!
By default Firefox is optimized for dial-up connections and that is why this feature isn't enabled from the start, so bear in mind that you should only do this if you have something better than a 56k dial-up connection(which most people should have in this day and age).
By default Firefox works like this, for instance, when you go to www.runescape.com this is what happens:
Download picture 1, download picture 2, download picture 3, download that text, and so forth. -------------1--------------------------2-----------------------3----------------------------4------------------5------------...
This feature will make Firefox work like this
Download picture 1----------------Page fully loaded Download picture 2 Download picture 3 Download that text and so forth -------------1-------------------------------------2---------------
So instead of waiting 5 seconds, you only have to wait 2. Liek omfg hax?!
And how do we achieve this? Well it is a lot easier than you may think!
Open Firefox, and at the address field type "about:config". A lot of stuff should be on your screen. At the Filter field type "network.http". Lesser things should be on your screen.
Maneuver yourself down to these lines and do the following:
Change network.http.pipelining to "true" Change network.http.proxy.pipelining to "true" Change network.http.pipelining.maxrequests to something like 30 (this will allow Firefox to make 30 requests at once)
Lastly, and I'm not sure if its necessary or not but do this. Right-click anywhere and select New -> Integer, name it “nglayout.initialpaint.delay” and set it's value to “0";. This option apparently sets the amount of time the browser waits before it acts on the information it receives.
OK, you should be done now and Firefox should load up pages faster than usual.
If it didn't work, go do something else ;)

item.title: For all you firefox hoes
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

FastBawlz:

…Well a couple of Mods and Admins looked at this and no one noticed its in the wrong section?

It’s fine where it is.

item.title: For all you firefox hoes
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:7, topic:134613”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=186011.msg1683128#msg1683128 date=1187417645]
I would keep the max requests rather low If I were you, it is hard on servers and some servers even block you if you attempt to have that many simultaneous connections thinking that you are some type of attacking bot.
[/quote]

I forgot about that. But yeah, some servers block multiple requests with up to 5 seconds of each other. :[/quote]

so thats the reason runehq hated me making almost 7,000 connections (3,400 webpages, 3,400 images)

PHP FTW?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I would keep the max requests rather low If I were you, it is hard on servers and some servers even block you if you attempt to have that many simultaneous connections thinking that you are some type of attacking bot.

I forgot about that. But yeah, some servers block multiple requests with up to 5 seconds of each other. :\

Read full topic

item.title: For all you firefox hoes
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“gikid, post:1, topic:134624”]Old, but forgot to do this after I formatted… Thanks for the reminder!

[edit]
I was checking this out and I found a note

Note: Pipelining is not well-supported by some servers and proxies. Things may break — use with caution.

:|[/quote]

You can keep it disabled for Proxy’s if you want.

Divine-Devil:

I set it to 100 instead of 30 >.>

Be careful when setting it high, I rarely doubt any page will have more than 30 objects, but if you try and download them all at once, it will be slower than before, an ideal amount is 10.

Read full topic

item.title: For all you firefox hoes
item.dc:creator: @wixter wixter
item.description:
@wixter wrote:

Well, i came across this very nice feature that sort of speeds up your Firefox by changing the way it works. This feature will make your Firefox browser load multiple things at the same time instead of just one thing.

This feature is Pipelining!

By default Firefox is optimized for dial-up connections and that is why this feature isn’t enabled from the start, so bear in mind that you should only do this if you have something better than a 56k dial-up connection(which most people should have in this day and age).

Download picture 1, download picture 2, download picture 3, download that text, and so forth.
-------------1--------------------------2-----------------------3----------------------------4------------------5------------…

This feature will make Firefox work like this

Download picture 1----------------Page fully loaded
Download picture 2
Download picture 3
Download that text
and so forth
-------------1-------------------------------------2---------------

So instead of waiting 5 seconds, you only have to wait 2. Liek omfg hax?!

And how do we achieve this? Well it is a lot easier than you may think!

Open Firefox, and at the address field type “about:config”. A lot of stuff should be on your screen. At the Filter field type “network.http”. Lesser things should be on your screen.

Lastly, and I’m not sure if its necessary or not but do this. Right-click anywhere and select New -> Integer, name it “nglayout.initialpaint.delay” and set it’s value to “0";. This option apparently sets the amount of time the browser waits before it acts on the information it receives.

OK, you should be done now and Firefox should load up pages faster than usual.

If it didn’t work, go do something else
